questions.questionsTitle: Get up early every day. (Write all that you do next.)

subQuestion.question: Get up early every day. (Write all that you do next.)
subQuestion.ans: Wake Up Early:Start my day by waking up at 5:30 a.m.

questions.questionsTitle: Special Features of Daily Routine.

subQuestion.question: I feel fresh whole day as I exercise every morning.
subQuestion.ans: Feeling Fresh:Morning exercise boosts my energy and keeps me fresh all day.

questions.questionsTitle: Discuss statements made under the Daily Routine and special features based on it. Appreciate significant points. Focus on the importance of adopting an active lifestyle.

subQuestion.question: Discuss statements made under the Daily Routine and special features based on it. Appreciate significant points. Focus on the importance of adopting an active lifestyle.
subQuestion.ans: Key Points and Their Significance:Waking Up Early:Starting the day early offers quiet, uninterrupted time to focus on oneself.It allows for better time management and sets a positive tone for the day.Studies show that early risers are often more proactive and better at problem-solving.Morning Exercise:Exercising in the morning energizes the body and boosts endorphin levels, leading to improved mood and mental clarity.It enhances physical fitness, promotes cardiovascular health, and helps maintain a healthy weight.Regular exercise is also linked to reduced stress and better sleep patterns.Healthy Breakfast:A nutritious breakfast fuels the body and brain, improving concentration and performance throughout the day.It helps regulate metabolism and prevents energy slumps later in the morning.Planning and prioritizing tasks:Organizing tasks early in the day enhances productivity by providing clear goals and reducing decision fatigue.Prioritization ensures that the most important work is completed during peak energy levels.Taking Breaks:Short breaks prevent burnout and help maintain focus.They also support physical health by reducing the strain of prolonged sitting.Evening Relaxation and Night Routine:Ending the day with relaxation activities helps unwind, reduces stress, and improves sleep quality.Journaling and reflecting on the day promote self-awareness and personal growth.

questions.questionsTitle: Make a list of grains, fruits, vegetables, leafy vegetables, vegetables grown in the wild and the fruits that you eat.

subQuestion.question: Make a list of grains, fruits, vegetables, leafy vegetables, vegetables grown in the wild and the fruits that you eat.
subQuestion.ans: Rice

subAns.Column 3: RiceWheatOatsBarleyQuinoaCornMillet (e.g., Pearl millet, Finger millet)
ApplesBananasOrangesMangoesGrapesPapayasWatermelonsStrawberriesBlueberriesPomegranates
CarrotsPotatoesTomatoesCucumbersBell Peppers (Capsicum)Eggplants (Brinjal)ZucchiniOkra (Lady's Finger)PumpkinRadishes
SpinachKaleLettuceFenugreek (Methi)Coriander LeavesMustard GreensSwiss ChardCollard GreensAmaranth Leaves
Wild MushroomsBamboo ShootsFiddlehead FernsWild AsparagusPurslaneDandelion Greens
Wild Berries (e.g., Blackberries, Raspberries)Guava (sometimes found wild)Custard Apple (Wild varieties)Bael (Wood Apple)Jamun (Indian Black Plum)Mulberries

questions.questionsTitle: Write about the need to clean our body parts.

subQuestion.question: Skin: Daily bathing makes our skin clean and healthy.
subQuestion.ans: Skin:Daily Bathing:Regular bathing removes sweat, dirt, dead skin cells, and bacteria.Benefits:Prevents skin infections and acne.Keeps the skin healthy, soft, and radiant.Promotes good hygiene and reduces body odour.

subQuestion.question: Ears: ______
subQuestion.ans: Daily Bathing:Regular bathing removes sweat, dirt, dead skin cells, and bacteria.Benefits:Prevents skin infections and acne.Keeps the skin healthy, soft, and radiant.Promotes good hygiene and reduces body odour.

subQuestion.question: Nose: ______
subQuestion.ans: Benefits:Prevents skin infections and acne.Keeps the skin healthy, soft, and radiant.Promotes good hygiene and reduces body odour.

subQuestion.question: Teeth: ______
subQuestion.ans: Prevents skin infections and acne.

subQuestion.question: Hands: ______
subQuestion.ans: Keeps the skin healthy, soft, and radiant.

subQuestion.question: Hair: ______
subQuestion.ans: Promotes good hygiene and reduces body odour.

subQuestion.question: Eyes: ______
subQuestion.ans: Ears:Regular Cleaning:The outer ear should be cleaned gently to remove dirt and excess wax.Benefits:It prevents the buildup of ear wax, which can impair hearing.Reduces the risk of ear infections and itching.Caution:Avoid inserting sharp objects or cotton swabs deep into the ear canal to prevent damage.

questions.questionsTitle: Tell the importance of personal cleanliness. After due discussion, ensure that the students learn to be responsible for personal as well as environmental cleanliness.

subQuestion.question: Tell the importance of personal cleanliness. After due discussion, ensure that the students learn to be responsible for personal as well as environmental cleanliness.
subQuestion.ans: Benefits of Personal Cleanliness:Prevents diseases and infections:Regular washing of hands, bathing, and oral care reduce the risk of illnesses caused by bacteria, viruses, and fungi.Good hygiene prevents skin infections, respiratory diseases, and foodborne illnesses.Promotes mental well-being:Feeling clean boosts confidence and self-esteem.Cleanliness helps reduce stress and provides a sense of comfort and dignity.Improves social interactions:Cleanliness reduces body odor and ensures a fresh appearance, fostering positive social relationships.It reflects respect for oneself and others, encouraging mutual respect in society.Enhances Productivity:Personal cleanliness contributes to better focus, motivation, and energy levels, enhancing overall productivity in school, work, and daily tasks.

questions.questionsTitle: List your good habits.

subQuestion.question: List your good habits.
subQuestion.ans: Personal hygiene and cleanliness:Taking a daily bath to maintain a clean and fresh appearance.Brushing teeth twice a day for oral health.Washing hands regularly, especially before meals and after using the restroom.Wearing clean and well-ironed clothes.

questions.questionsTitle: Tell the importance of exercise, rest and sleep in human life.

subQuestion.question: Tell the importance of exercise, rest and sleep in human life.
subQuestion.ans:
Exercise:Exercise plays a pivotal role in maintaining overall health and well-being.
Its benefits include:Physical Health:Improves cardiovascular health by strengthening the heart and improving blood circulation.Enhances muscle strength, flexibility, and endurance.Aids in weight management by burning calories and boosting metabolism.Reduces the risk of chronic diseases like diabetes, hypertension, and osteoporosis.Mental Health:Boosts the release of endorphins, also known as "feel-good" hormones, which reduce stress and improve mood.Helps combat depression and anxiety.Improves cognitive function and memory by increasing blood flow to the brain.

questions.questionsTitle: Inform about the ill effects of bad habits.

subQuestion.question: Inform about the ill effects of bad habits.
subQuestion.ans: Smoking:Increases the risk of lung cancer, heart disease, and respiratory problems.

questions.questionsTitle: Observe the images and tell the class what first aid you will provide.

subQuestion.ans: Cut:Wash your hands to prevent infection.Clean the wound gently with water to remove dirt.Apply an antiseptic.Cover with a sterile bandage.Apply gentle pressure if bleeding continues.
Wash your hands to prevent infection.
Clean the wound gently with water to remove dirt.
Apply an antiseptic.
Cover with a sterile bandage.

questions.questionsTitle: Observe the pictures and collect information about required first aid. Learn about the things in the first aid box and their uses.

subQuestion.question: Observe the pictures and collect information about required first aid. Learn about the things in the first aid box and their uses.
subQuestion.ans: Antiseptic Solution (e.g., Dettol, Savlon):Cleans wounds to prevent infections.

questions.questionsTitle: Have a discussion about the first aid materials required and their uses/how to use them. Give necessary guidance. Inform the students about school first aid box and how to use the things in it.

subQuestion.question: Have a discussion about the first aid materials required and their uses/how to use them. Give necessary guidance. Inform the students about school first aid box and how to use the things in it.
subQuestion.ans:
Antiseptic Solution (e.g., Dettol, Savlon):Cleans wounds to prevent infection.
Apply a small amount to a clean cotton swab and gently clean the wound.

questions.questionsTitle: Take rangoli or soft soil/sand in a big dish or a tray to practice lines on it using a stick or with a finger. Make diagrams of wavy and intersecting lines using thick wool.

subQuestion.question: Take rangoli or soft soil/sand in a big dish or a tray to practice lines on it using a stick or with a finger. Make diagrams of wavy and intersecting lines using thick wool.
subQuestion.ans: Big Dish or Tray– filled with rangoli powder, soft soil, or fine sand.

questions.questionsTitle: Make the children practice wavy and intersecting lines. Make them use different mediums like coloured pencils, crayons, coloured pens or sketch pens for practice.

subQuestion.question: Make the children practice wavy and intersecting lines. Make them use different mediums like coloured pencils, crayons, coloured pens or sketch pens for practice.
subQuestion.ans: To improve fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination.

questions.questionsTitle: Explain to children the difference between geometrical, natural, ornamental and abstract shapes and ask them to draw such shapes.

subQuestion.question: Explain to children the difference between geometrical, natural, ornamental and abstract shapes and ask them to draw such shapes.
subQuestion.ans:
Step 1: Introduction to Shapes:Start by telling the children that shapes are all around us, and they come in different types.
Explain the following categories with simple examples:Geometrical Shapes:These are precise and regular shapes with clear edges and angles.Examples: Circle, square, rectangle, triangle, hexagon.Show them objects like a box (rectangle), a ball (circle), or a slice of pizza (triangle).Natural Shapes:These are irregular and found in nature.Examples: leaves, flowers, clouds, rocks, and animal shapes.Show them real leaves or images of flowers and clouds.Ornamental Shapes:These are decorative shapes often used in designs, patterns, or jewelry.Examples: borders, mandalas, paisley designs, and intricate patterns.Show them decorative artwork or embroidery.Abstract Shapes:These are imaginative and don't represent real objects; they can be random or symbolic.Examples: swirls, blobs, unique patterns, or modern art designs.Show them abstract art or patterns.

questions.questionsTitle: Use a match box or a box of stapler pins as parts of body, a marble or a betel nut as a face, use sticks for neck, hands, legs to show/make different movements of human figures.

subQuestion.question: Use a match box or a box of stapler pins as parts of body, a marble or a betel nut as a face, use sticks for neck, hands, legs to show/make different movements of human figures.
subQuestion.ans: Materials Needed:MatchboxorBox of Stapler Pins– for the torso.MarbleorBetel Nut– for the head.Sticks(toothpicks, ice cream sticks, or matchsticks) – for the neck, hands, and legs.Glue or Tape– to attach the parts.Markers or Paint– to decorate or add details (optional).Create the Body:Use the matchbox or stapler pin box as the torso of the figure.Add the Head:Attach a marble or betel nut to the top of the matchbox using glue or tape.Make the Neck:Connect the head and torso with a stick to form the neck.Attach Arms and Legs:Use sticks for the arms and legs.Attach the arms to the sides of the matchbox and the legs at the bottom.

questions.questionsTitle: Narrate any imaginary story in your group, draw any of the imaginary incidents from the story and colour it.

subQuestion.question: Narrate any imaginary story in your group, draw any of the imaginary incidents from the story and colour it.
subQuestion.ans:
Step 2:Drawing an Imaginary Scene:Ask the children to choose their favorite scene from the story to draw.
Some ideas:Lila Finding the Glowing Key:Draw Lila in a garden with the glowing key in her hand.The Magical Forest:Draw trees with faces, talking animals, and sparkling rivers.Flying on a Dragon:Draw Lila riding a dragon over the forest.The Golden Door and Treasure Chest:Draw the castle with the golden door and the glowing crystals inside.

questions.questionsTitle: Use different shapes as designs inside a circle and colour them.

subQuestion.question: Use different shapes as designs inside a circle and colour them.
subQuestion.ans: Here is a diagram illustrating how different shapes can be used as designs inside a circle.

questions.questionsTitle: Make students understand the use of a ruler and compass while drawing geometrical shapes. Guide them properly about how to colour them and show some specimens of designs.

subQuestion.question: Make students understand the use of a ruler and compass while drawing geometrical shapes. Guide them properly about how to colour them and show some specimens of designs.
subQuestion.ans: Circle (Compass):Use a compass to draw a perfect circle.

questions.questionsTitle: Sprinkle the school playground with water and notice the designs created. Prepare different types of stencils to make spray paintings.

subQuestion.question: Sprinkle the school playground with water and notice the designs created. Prepare different types of stencils to make spray paintings.
subQuestion.ans: Sprinkle Water on the Playground:Lightly sprinkle water across the school playground.Observe the natural designs formed by the water patterns (e.g., streaks, spots).

questions.questionsTitle: Put a big chart on a wall and organize a group activity where children spray colours upon the chart using their hands.

subQuestion.question: Put a big chart on a wall and organize a group activity where children spray colours upon the chart using their hands.
subQuestion.ans: Prepare the Chart:Hang a large chart paper on a wall in a well-ventilated area.

questions.questionsTitle: Tell the students what a stencil is and how to make it. Also show them how to use it.

subQuestion.question: Tell the students what a stencil is and how to make it. Also show them how to use it.
subQuestion.ans: How to Make a Stencil:Materials Needed:A sheet of cardboard, plastic, or thick paperPencil or markerScissors or a craft knifeRulerTape

questions.questionsTitle: Cut the shapes of vases, flowers, leaves, butterflies using papers of colourful pictures in newspapers or magazines and paste them to prepare pretty greeting cards.

subQuestion.question: Cut the shapes of vases, flowers, leaves, butterflies using papers of colourful pictures in newspapers or magazines and paste them to prepare pretty greeting cards.
subQuestion.ans: Materials Needed:Colored papers, magazines, scissors, glue, and a blank card.

questions.questionsTitle: Show the students how various materials like bindis, kundans, beads, sand, conch shells, rangoli, pieces of bangles, buttons, matchsticks, etc. can be used in collage art. Show them some examples of it.

subQuestion.question: Show the students how various materials like bindis, kundans, beads, sand, conch shells, rangoli, pieces of bangles, buttons, matchsticks, etc. can be used in collage art. Show them some examples of it.
subQuestion.ans: Elements:Bindi Flower:Red center with magenta petals.Kundans & Beads:Green kundans with gold beads.Bangles & Buttons:Mosaic of bangle pieces and orange buttons.Matchstick Frame:Border made of matchsticks.

questions.questionsTitle: Practice writing letters using graph papers or square lined notebooks.

subQuestion.question: Practice writing letters using graph papers or square lined notebooks.
subQuestion.ans: Purpose:Improve handwriting by focusing on letter size, spacing, and alignment.

questions.questionsTitle: Introduce shapes of letters, aesthetic designs in a simple, easy way.

subQuestion.question: Introduce shapes of letters, aesthetic designs in a simple, easy way.
subQuestion.ans: Break Letters into Shapes:Show how letters are made of basic shapes like lines, circles, and angles.Examples: "A" = 2 slanted lines + 1 horizontal, "B" = 1 straight line + 2 semi-circles.

questions.questionsTitle: Make easy, simple sketches of manmade and natural objects.

subQuestion.question: Make easy, simple sketches of manmade and natural objects.
subQuestion.ans:
Natural Objects:Tree:Draw a vertical rectangle for the trunk.
Add a cloud-like shape on top for foliage.Mountain:Draw three connected triangles.
Add a wavy line near the top for snow.Sun:Draw a circle for the sun.
Add short lines radiating outward.

questions.questionsTitle: Show various objects of different shapes to the students to find out to which shape it matches. Initiate discussion.

subQuestion.question: Show various objects of different shapes to the students to find out to which shape it matches. Initiate discussion.
subQuestion.ans: Circle:Matches with a ball.

questions.questionsTitle: Show students different objects which are in everyday use and related with each other as well as the inter-related pairs of such objects. For example- cup and saucer, bat and ball, etc.

subQuestion.question: Show students different objects which are in everyday use and related with each other as well as the inter-related pairs of such objects. For example- cup and saucer, bat and ball, etc.
subQuestion.ans: Cup and Saucer

questions.questionsTitle: Try making paper lanterns of different colours.

subQuestion.question: Try making paper lanterns of different colours.
subQuestion.ans: Prepare the Paper:Take a colourful A4 sheet.Fold it lengthwise in half.

subQuestion.question: Stick dried grass, leaves and flowers on a paper to make a birds' nest picture.
subQuestion.ans: Dried grass, leaves, and flowers (collected and pressed)

questions.questionsTitle: Using the soil available in your surroundings, make a flat, square block. Decorate it with designs of clay rolls as per your choice and make a photo frame of it.

subQuestion.question: Using the soil available in your surroundings, make a flat, square block. Decorate it with designs of clay rolls as per your choice and make a photo frame of it.
subQuestion.ans: Prepare Clay: Mix soil with water; knead into a smooth dough.

questions.questionsTitle: Show the children the clay models of birds, animals, toys, objects, etc. and ask the students to give some different demonstrations.

subQuestion.question: Show the children the clay models of birds, animals, toys, objects, etc. and ask the students to give some different demonstrations.
subQuestion.ans: Objective:Encourage creativity by making clay models and presenting them.

questions.questionsTitle: With your own imagination, make paper models and write what they can be used for.

subQuestion.question: With your own imagination, make paper models and write what they can be used for.
subQuestion.ans: Boat:For water play and learning about buoyancy.

questions.questionsTitle: Ask the students to make various paper models by pasting pieces of paper. Organize an exhibition of their creations.

subQuestion.question: Ask the students to make various paper models by pasting pieces of paper. Organize an exhibition of their creations.
subQuestion.ans: Objective:Encourage creativity and teamwork through crafting and showcasing paper models.

questions.questionsTitle: With your imagination, make paper models like photo frames, basket, mat, letters, etc. by making rolls of the newspapers.

subQuestion.question: With your imagination, make paper models like photo frames, basket, mat, letters, etc. by making rolls of the newspapers.
subQuestion.ans: Materials:Newspapers, glue, scissors, optional paint/decorations.

questions.questionsTitle: Tell the students that shapes which have length, breadth, as well as thickness or depth, are called three-dimensional models.

subQuestion.question: Tell the students that shapes which have length, breadth, as well as thickness or depth, are called three-dimensional models.
subQuestion.ans: Definition:Explain that 3D models have length, width, and depth, unlike flat 2D shapes.

questions.questionsTitle: Make models with your imagination using waste material available to you.

subQuestion.question: Make models with your imagination using waste material available to you.
subQuestion.ans: Cardboard Mini House:Build a house with cardboard, paper scraps, and bottle caps for windows.

questions.questionsTitle: Get the models done as per choice of the students, using some other mediums as per the material available.

subQuestion.question: Get the models done as per choice of the students, using some other mediums as per the material available.
subQuestion.ans: Tissue Box Train:Use tissue boxes for compartments and plastic lids for wheels.

questions.questionsTitle: Write the name and some information about each of the animals shown in the pictures below.

subQuestion.question: Write the name and some information about each of the animals shown in the pictures below.
subQuestion.ans: AnimalDescriptionHabitatDietImagesBuffaloLarge farm animals are used for milk and farming.Farms, grassy areasHerbivoreGoatSmall animal known for milk and meat.Farms, hilly regionsHerbivoreSheepProvides wool and meat.Grasslands, farmsHerbivoreCatSmall, domesticated pet.Homes, urban areasCarnivoreRoosterMale chicken known for crowing.Farms, rural areasOmnivoreElephantLarge animal with trunk and tusks.Forests, savannasHerbivoreDogLoyal and friendly pet.Homes, urban areasOmnivoreHorseUsed for transport and work.Farms, grasslandsHerbivoreCamelDesert animals adapted for survival without water.Deserts, arid regionsHerbivore

subAns.Column 2: Large farm animals are used for milk and farming.

questions.questionsTitle: Explain the uses of domestic animals according to their uses at the local level.

subQuestion.question: Explain the uses of domestic animals according to their uses at the local level.
subQuestion.ans: AnimalLocal Uses1.CowProvides milk, hides (leather), and dung for fuel or fertilizer.2.DonkeyUsed for carrying loads, transporting goods, and agricultural work.3.ChickenProvides eggs and meat; helps control insects on farms.4.DuckProvides eggs, meat, and feathers; helps control pests in rice fields.5.PigRaised for meat (pork) and sometimes manure for fertilization.6.RabbitRaised for meat, fur, and as pets, manure is used as fertilizer.7.PigeonUsed for meat, as pets, and for communication in traditional practices.8.Bee (Honeybee)Produces honey and beeswax and helps pollinate crops.9.Fish (Aquaculture)Provides a source of protein; fish farming supports local food systems.10.CamelProvides milk, meat, and transportation; used in trade and farming in deserts.11.HorseUsed for transport, plowing fields, and recreational riding.12.GooseRaised for meat, eggs, feathers, and as guards for property.13.CatKeeps homes and farms free from rodents; provides companionship.14.DogGuards property, herds livestock, helps in hunting, and offers companionship.

subAns.Column 3: Provides milk, hides (leather), and dung for fuel or fertilizer.
Used for carrying loads, transporting goods, and agricultural work.
Provides eggs and meat; helps control insects on farms.
Provides eggs, meat, and feathers; helps control pests in rice fields.
Raised for meat (pork) and sometimes manure for fertilization.
Raised for meat, fur, and as pets, manure is used as fertilizer.
Used for meat, as pets, and for communication in traditional practices.
Produces honey and beeswax and helps pollinate crops.
Provides a source of protein; fish farming supports local food systems.
Provides milk, meat, and transportation; used in trade and farming in deserts.
Used for transport, plowing fields, and recreational riding.
Raised for meat, eggs, feathers, and as guards for property.
Keeps homes and farms free from rodents; provides companionship.
Guards property, herds livestock, helps in hunting, and offers companionship.

questions.questionsTitle: Make the students understand the relation of both the positions and the running distance. Teach them to use the positions before and during the race. Inform the students about the types of the athletic sports.

subQuestion.question: Make the students understand the relation of both the positions and the running distance. Teach them to use the positions before and during the race. Inform the students about the types of the athletic sports.
subQuestion.ans: Relation Between Positions and Distances:Starting position impacts effort and strategy.Example:Staggered starts ensure fairness in curved tracks; inner lane advantage is compensated.Activity:Set up races to demonstrate staggered starts and their effect on distance.

questions.questionsTitle: Demonstrate to the students the activities in, the ABC Drills.

subQuestion.question: Demonstrate to the students the activities in, the ABC Drills.
subQuestion.ans: A Drill (High Knees):Focus on lifting knees to hip level, landing on the balls of the feet, and pumping arms in sync.Perform for 20 meters, increasing speed gradually.

questions.questionsTitle: Teach Lezium Basic position and ask the students to play the Double Beats, Four Beats and Eight Beats in rhythm

subQuestion.question: Teach Lezium Basic position and ask the students to play the Double Beats, Four Beats and Eight Beats in rhythm
subQuestion.ans: Basic Position:Stand upright, feet shoulder-width apart.Hold the Lezium stick firmly with bent arms and relaxed shoulders.Demonstrate wrist action to produce rhythmic claps.

questions.questionsTitle: Give a presentation of the lezium unit on various occasions in the school.

subQuestion.question: Give a presentation of the lezium unit on various occasions in the school.
subQuestion.ans:
Introduction:Briefly explain Lezium's cultural and fitness significance.
Use background music or drumbeats for an engaging entry.

questions.questionsTitle: Practise the Dumbbells Types.

subQuestion.question: Practise the Dumbbells Types.
subQuestion.ans:
Upper Body ExercisesBicep Curl:BicepsHold a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing forward.Bend your elbows and curl the weights toward your shoulders.
Lower slowly.Reps: 10-12 per set.Overhead Press:Shoulders and tricepsHold dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing forward.Press the weights upward until arms are fully extended, then lower.Reps: 8-10 per set.Bent-Over Row:Upper backBend forward at the waist with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended downward.Pull the dumbbells toward your waist and lower slowly.Reps: 10-12 per set.

questions.questionsTitle: Teach different types of dumbbell exercises. Encourage them to innovate and learn new types of exercises.

subQuestion.question: Teach different types of dumbbell exercises. Encourage them to innovate and learn new types of exercises.
subQuestion.ans: Basic Dumbbell Exercises:Upper Body:Bicep Curl, Overhead Press, Bent-Over Row.Lower Body:Squats, Lunges.Core:Russian Twists, Side Bends.Full-body:Deadlifts, Thrusters.

questions.questionsTitle: Practice different aerobic exercises with music. Practise Human Pyramid in your presence.

subQuestion.question: Practice different aerobic exercises with music. Practise Human Pyramid in your presence.
subQuestion.ans: Aerobic Exercises with MusicWarm-Up (5-10 min):Light marching, side steps with claps, and arm circles to start.Main Session (20-30 min):Basic Moves:Jumping jacks, high knees, and punches.Dance aerobics:Add fun movements like Zumba or salsa.Intervals:Alternate high-energy moves (burpees) with lighter steps.Cool Down (5-10 min):Gradually slow down, followed by stretches for major muscle groups.

questions.questionsTitle: Introduction to musical instruments.

subQuestion.question: Introduction to musical instruments.
subQuestion.ans:
Harmonium:Harmonium is a popular instrument in Hindustani music.
As this instrument is played with the help of wind, it is called a wind instrument.
It is used to accompany the singer as well as in a solo performance.

questions.questionsTitle: Introduction to Background Music.

subQuestion.question: Introduction to Background Music.
subQuestion.ans: Flute offers a soothing and melodic feel.

questions.questionsTitle: Practice various Mudras used in dance. Using your fingers, perform mudras of birds and animals to cast their shadows on the wall.

subQuestion.question: Practice various Mudras used in dance. Using your fingers, perform mudras of birds and animals to cast their shadows on the wall.
subQuestion.ans: Hamsasya Mudra (Swan):Form a circle with your thumb and index finger, keeping the other fingers extended.

questions.questionsTitle: Visit the local Women's Self-Help Group and obtain information about the industries and occupations seen there.

subQuestion.question: Visit the local Women's Self-Help Group and obtain information about the industries and occupations seen there.
subQuestion.ans:
Shri Mahila Griha Udyog Lijjat Papad:A renowned women's cooperative founded in 1959, primarily involved in the production of papads, along with other products like spices, flour, and bakery items.
It provides employment to over 45,000 women across India.

questions.questionsTitle: Obtain information about industries other than those mentioned in the textbook.

subQuestion.question: Obtain information about industries other than those mentioned in the textbook.
subQuestion.ans: Homemade Chocolate Production:With the growing demand for artisanal and homemade chocolates, this industry offers opportunities for entrepreneurs to cater to niche markets seeking quality confectioneries.

questions.questionsTitle: Give guidance regarding proper waste management and disposal and about reuse and recycling.

subQuestion.question: Give guidance regarding proper waste management and disposal and about reuse and recycling.
subQuestion.ans:
Guidance on Proper Waste Management and Disposal:Segregate Waste:Separate waste into categories: biodegradable (food scraps, paper), non-biodegradable (plastic, metal), and hazardous (batteries, chemicals).
Use labeled bins for each type.Dispose of waste responsibly:Use designated community or municipal waste disposal systems.Avoid littering in public spaces and always use trash bins.Handle hazardous waste properly:Dispose of hazardous materials like batteries, electronic waste, and chemicals at designated drop-off points to prevent environmental contamination.

questions.questionsTitle: Volunteer at a festival or other function. and write a detailed letter to a friend describing your experience.

subQuestion.question: Volunteer at a festival or other function. and write a detailed letter to a friend describing your experience.
subQuestion.ans: 10th January 2025535 Green StreetSpringfield,Mumbai- 45678.Dear Lucky,How are you?

questions.questionsTitle: Give guidance to children of different age groups to work as volunteers.

subQuestion.question: Give guidance to children of different age groups to work as volunteers.
subQuestion.ans: Ages 5–7 Small Acts of Kindness:At this age, volunteering should focus on simple, fun, and interactive activities that build foundational values of empathy and sharing.Helping neighbors:Accompany parents to deliver baked goods or groceries to elderly neighbors.Community clean-up:Participate in a park or playground cleanup, picking up litter with adult supervision.Making cards or crafts:Create thank-you gifts or drawings for hospital staff, first responders, or nursing home residents.Animal shelters:Donate gently used blankets or toys for pets, accompanied by parents.

questions.questionsTitle: Guide the students about how to use a water meter. Show them the water reservoirs in the village/town/city and explain to them their capacity. Give proper guidance when conducting the experiment for measuring rainfall.

subQuestion.question: Guide the students about how to use a water meter. Show them the water reservoirs in the village/town/city and explain to them their capacity. Give proper guidance when conducting the experiment for measuring rainfall.
subQuestion.ans:
Using a Water Meter:A water meter measures the water consumed in households or communities.
Here's how to teach students:Steps to use a water meter:Locate the water meter:Show students where the meter is installed (usually near the main water line or outside the house).Explain the parts of the meter: display, dials, and unit of measurement (litres or cubic meters).Read the water meter:Show students how to note the numbers on the meter.Explain that the difference between two readings (e.g., from morning to evening) shows the water used during that time.Practical activity:Ask students to measure water usage for a specific task, like filling a bucket or washing dishes.Teach them to calculate daily or weekly water consumption at home.

questions.questionsTitle: Write in short and draw a picture on the topic, 'This is how water comes to my house'. Make a model of a water carrier.

subQuestion.question: Write in short and draw a picture on the topic, 'This is how water comes to my house'. Make a model of a water carrier.
subQuestion.ans: Source:Water is collected from a reservoir, river, or underground.

questions.questionsTitle: Have a picture-reading and discussion or show a video or filmstrip introducing the children to the different methods of transporting water.

subQuestion.question: Have a picture-reading and discussion or show a video or filmstrip introducing the children to the different methods of transporting water.
subQuestion.ans: Picture-Reading Activity Preparation:Gather images that depict various water transportation methods, such asBuckets (used in rural areas or traditional communities)Pipes and aqueductsWater trucksIrrigation systemsBoats or barges carrying waterModern water distribution systems (e.g., city pipelines)

questions.questionsTitle: Collect slogans relating to a disaster like an earthquake, flood or COVID-19. Collect clippings of news items or pictures of a cyclone or tsunami. Make a list of the aid that you can give to those affected by a flood.

subQuestion.question: Collect slogans relating to a disaster like an earthquake, flood or COVID-19. Collect clippings of news items or pictures of a cyclone or tsunami. Make a list of the aid that you can give to those affected by a flood.
subQuestion.ans: Earthquake:"Prepare, don't panic - earthquakes strike without warning.""Stay low, stay safe during a quake.""Drop, Cover, Hold - your best earthquake defence."

questions.questionsTitle: Give information about the precautions to be taken before, during or after the occurrence of an earthquake, flood or epidemic.

subQuestion.question: Give information about the precautions to be taken before, during or after the occurrence of an earthquake, flood or epidemic.
subQuestion.ans: EarthquakeBefore an earthquake:Prepare Emergency Kits:Include water, food, flashlight, first aid, and essential documents.Secure Furniture and Appliances:Bolt heavy furniture to walls and secure appliances.Identify Safe Spots:Locate sturdy tables or interior walls to take cover.Develop an Emergency Plan:Establish meeting points and communication methods with family.During an earthquake:Drop, Cover, and Hold On:Drop to the ground, take cover under sturdy furniture, and hold on.Stay away from Glass and Heavy Objects:Avoid windows, mirrors, and anything that could fall.Remain Where You Are:Indoors: Stay inside; outdoors: Move to an open area.After an earthquake:Check for injuries and damage:Administer first aid and inspect for structural damage.Avoid using damaged buildings:Do not re-enter until deemed safe.Follow Official Instructions:Listen to emergency broadcasts and cooperate with authorities.

questions.questionsTitle: Make a variety of hats using old newspapers and gift them to your friends. Write out the procedure for making a hat and ask your friend to make a hat by following those instructions.

subQuestion.question: Make a variety of hats using old newspapers and gift them to your friends. Write out the procedure for making a hat and ask your friend to make a hat by following those instructions.
subQuestion.ans: Prepare:Lay a newspaper flat on the table.

questions.questionsTitle: Arrange an exhibition of the decorative hats made by the children.

subQuestion.question: Arrange an exhibition of the decorative hats made by the children.
subQuestion.ans: Set a Theme & Name:Choose a creative theme (e.g., "Hats Off to Creativity") to unify the event.

questions.questionsTitle: Make various kinds of tassels and hangings.

subQuestion.question: Make various kinds of tassels and hangings.
subQuestion.ans: TasselsClassic Yarn Tassel:Wrap yarn around cardboard, tie, cut loops, and fluff.Thread Tassel:Loop embroidery thread, tie, and add metallic accents.Beaded Tassel:Add beads to yarn or thread tassels.Fabric Tassel:Tie thin strips of fabric for a textured tassel.Macramé Tassel:Use cotton rope and tie into decorative knots.

questions.questionsTitle: Draw an artistic picture and decorate it with beads and string.

subQuestion.question: Draw an artistic picture and decorate it with beads and string.
subQuestion.ans: Paper, cardboard, or canvas

questions.questionsTitle: List new possible games using the given movements in your notebook. Prepare the rules of the new game and play with your friends.

subQuestion.question: List new possible games using the given movements in your notebook. Prepare the rules of the new game and play with your friends.
subQuestion.ans: Balance and Bend Challenge:Movements:Bend, balance, twist, stretch.Objective:Hold a pose incorporating balance and bending without losing form.Rules:Players take turns drawing a card with a specific pose (e.g., stand on one leg and stretch your arms).Each player must hold the pose for 10 seconds to earn a point.If a player loses balance or fails to hold the pose, they lose a turn.The player with the most points after 5 rounds wins.

questions.questionsTitle: Movements performed on the spot

subQuestion.question: Give information of the above movements. Initially, practice various movements. Encourage them to innovative and prepare a new game using the given movements. Guide them to create a new game and play it skilfully.
subQuestion.ans: Balance and Bend Challenge:Movements:Bend, balance, twist, stretch.Objective:Hold a pose incorporating balance and bending without losing form.Rules:Players take turns drawing a card with a specific pose (e.g., stand on one leg and stretch your arms).Each player must hold the pose for 10 seconds to earn a point.If a player loses balance or fails to hold the pose, they lose a turn.The player with the most points after 5 rounds wins.

questions.questionsTitle: Explain the parts of Drill Parade with some demonstrations.

subQuestion.question: Explain the parts of Drill Parade with some demonstrations.
subQuestion.ans:
Attention (Savdhan):This is the basic starting posture for a parade.
The participants stand upright, with their heels together, toes pointing outward, and arms straight down at their sides.Demonstration:Instruct participants to stand tall, chin up, and chest out.Show how to quickly snap into the "attention" position when the command "attention" is given.

questions.questionsTitle: Encourage the students to innovate and create new games using available props based on different movements. Focus on the habit of following the rules while playing. Pay attention to safety while playing. Use the book 'Small Games' published by Textbook Bureau (Balbharati), Pune to get more information.

subQuestion.question: Encourage the students to innovate and create new games using available props based on different movements. Focus on the habit of following the rules while playing. Pay attention to safety while playing. Use the book 'Small Games' published by Textbook Bureau (Balbharati), Pune to get more information.
subQuestion.ans:
Analyze Existing Games:From the image, games like Catching the Ball or Dog and the Bone involve simple, familiar rules.
Encourage students to observe the structure of these games What is the goal (e.g., scoring points, eliminating opponents).

questions.questionsTitle: The races described are given as samples. Select some movements and plan other such races. Explain the rules of the game to the students and ask them to focus on the rules and their own safety.

subQuestion.question: The races described are given as samples. Select some movements and plan other such races. Explain the rules of the game to the students and ask them to focus on the rules and their own safety.
subQuestion.ans: Hop and Clap Race:Movement:Students hop forward on two feet, and after each hop, they must clap their hands above their heads before taking the next hop.Rules:Participants must hop continuously without skipping a clap.If they miss a clap, they need to restart from where they made the mistake.The race ends when they cross the finish line while maintaining the pattern.

questions.questionsTitle: What is called the specific time for sowing?

subQuestion.question: What is called the specific time for sowing?
subQuestion.ans: Crop Type:Different crops have specific sowing times, such as Kharif, Rabi, or Zaid seasons in India.Kharif crops (e.g., rice, maize):Sown in the rainy season (June - July).Rabi crops(e.g., wheat, mustard):Sown in the winter season (October - November).Zaid crops(e.g., cucumber, watermelon):Sown between Rabi and Kharif (March - June).

questions.questionsTitle: Visit an oil mill to observe how oil is pressed out of oil seeds and write a description of the process.

subQuestion.question: Visit an oil mill to observe how oil is pressed out of oil seeds and write a description of the process.
subQuestion.ans: Collection and Cleaning:Seeds like mustard, sesame, or groundnut are delivered and cleaned to remove impurities using sifters and blowers.

subQuestion.question: Help the children to collect specimens of some crops.
subQuestion.ans: Select Crops:Choose common crops like wheat, rice, maize, or mustard based on availability.

questions.questionsTitle: Obtain information about charkhas by visiting a charkha museum or exhibition. Obtain more detailed information about one of the charkhas.

subQuestion.question: Obtain information about charkhas by visiting a charkha museum or exhibition. Obtain more detailed information about one of the charkhas.
subQuestion.ans:
Charkha and its Significance:The charkha, a traditional Indian spinning wheel, played a vital role in India's independence movement, symbolizing self-reliance and the Swadeshi movement.
Visiting Charkha museums offers insights into its evolution and historical importance.

questions.questionsTitle: Give information about weaving equipment using a charkha or pictures/videos of a charkha.

subQuestion.question: Give information about weaving equipment using a charkha or pictures/videos of a charkha.
subQuestion.ans:
Charkha Overview:The charkha, a traditional Indian spinning wheel, spins fibers like cotton into yarn and played a vital role in India's textile heritage and independence movement, symbolizing self-reliance.
It was championed by Mahatma Gandhi during the Swadeshi movement.

subQuestion.ans: Odav - 5 Swaras

subAns.Column 2: The number of Swaras in a particular Raga decides its Jati. Raga has three main types of Jati.Odav - 5 SwarasShadav - 6 SwardsSampuma - 7 Swaras
The composition of seven Swaras that have the capability to create the Raga.
The main Swara in the raga is called 'vadi swara.'
The important Swara next to Vadi is Samvadi.
A small Swara group in the Raga that is frequently played or sung is called the Pakad of Raga or Mukhyanga.

questions.questionsTitle: Practice different games and master the skills.

subQuestion.question: Practice different games and master the skills.
subQuestion.ans: Outdoor Games:Cricket:Practice batting, bowling, and fielding.Football:Focus on passing, dribbling, and shooting.Badminton:Work on serving, smashing, and quick footwork.Kho-Kho:Improve agility and quick decision-making.

questions.questionsTitle: Begin your period with some warm-up exercises. Make a habit of warming up before playing the games. Have innovative warm up exercises.

subQuestion.question: Begin your period with some warm-up exercises. Make a habit of warming up before playing the games. Have innovative warm up exercises.
subQuestion.ans: Dynamic Stretches:Walking Lunges with Twist:Lunge forward and twist your torso.Arm Swings with Step Back:Swing arms while stepping back.

questions.questionsTitle: Ensure that the students practice strengthening exercises regularly. Revise the strengthening exercises once in a month regularly and practice them. Keep a record of the physical development of the students.

subQuestion.question: Ensure that the students practice strengthening exercises regularly. Revise the strengthening exercises once in a month regularly and practice them. Keep a record of the physical development of the students.
subQuestion.ans: Strengthening Routine:Regular Practice:Schedule specific days for exercises like squats, push-ups, and planks.Monthly Updates:Revise and add variations to keep exercises engaging and effective.

questions.questionsTitle: Maintain a suitable physical position while performing Suryanamaskar. Encourage the students to perform Suryanamaskar every day. Arrange a group performance of Suryanamaskar on the occasion of Yoga Day.

subQuestion.question: Maintain a suitable physical position while performing Suryanamaskar. Encourage the students to perform Suryanamaskar every day. Arrange a group performance of Suryanamaskar on the occasion of Yoga Day.
subQuestion.ans: Daily Practice:Proper Form:Teach correct posture and breathing to maximize benefits and prevent injuries.Regular Routine:Encourage daily practice, gradually increasing repetitions for improved stamina and flexibility.

questions.questionsTitle: Which Asanas can you perform from the given list? Learn different asanas and practice them in the morning/evening.

subQuestion.question: Which Asanas can you perform from the given list? Learn different asanas and practice them in the morning/evening.
subQuestion.ans: Standing Asanas:Tadasana, Trikonasana, Vrikshasana

questions.questionsTitle: Introduce Yoga to the students and encourage them to follow the rules and regulations of the (Yam and Niyam). Ensure that the students practice different Asanas and Pranayam daily.

subQuestion.question: Introduce Yoga to the students and encourage them to follow the rules and regulations of the (Yam and Niyam). Ensure that the students practice different Asanas and Pranayam daily.
subQuestion.ans: Yoga Introduction:Definition & Benefits:Explain yoga as the union of mind, body, and soul, promoting health, mental well-being, and discipline.Yama & Niyama:Teach ethical principles such as Yamas (e.g., non-violence, truthfulness) and Niyamas (e.g., cleanliness, contentment) to instill values.

questions.questionsTitle: Develop skills for an obstacle race using various basic movements and sporting skills. Get the students to innovate and design new obstacle races and to run those races. It will enable the development of basic movement.

subQuestion.question: Develop skills for an obstacle race using various basic movements and sporting skills. Get the students to innovate and design new obstacle races and to run those races. It will enable the development of basic movement.
subQuestion.ans: Objective:Develop students' movement skills, creativity, and teamwork through designing and participating in obstacle races.

questions.questionsTitle: Have various programmes for physical fitness development.

subQuestion.question: Have various programmes for physical fitness development.
subQuestion.ans: Cardiovascular Fitness:Running/walking clubs, Zumba, and cycling to improve endurance.

questions.questionsTitle: Have different activities for developing the motor strength.

subQuestion.question: Have different activities for developing the motor strength.
subQuestion.ans: Upper Body:Push-ups, pull-ups, planks, and medicine ball throws.

Sindhu, Neeraj Chopra, Mary Kom, Major Dhyan Chand, and others, focusing on their achievements and contributions.
